Articles.Content:
Do you use OneNote?

If so, how do you use it and on what devices?

OneNote is brilliant for taking notes and keeping everything important in one place.

It's a shame students don't use it more, because it is so easy and flexible.

I use it on my PC, iPad and iPhone. With the recent update to the iOS app, I even bought a precision stylus for my Ipad to easily jot things down on it. After all, when you are writing with your hand you remember a lot more than you do with typing.

After that, you can convert formulas, equations and regular old text into digital text!

The vector graphics are awesome too. You can draw a house and easily change the roof color, you can cut a text from the net and underline/highlight anything freely. It all just feels so natural.

I even made a OneNote for my class. More than half uses it and we can write in homework for each subject and store learning materials inside. There is also a fun zone where you can draw or write anything you want.

OneNote is like Word, Excel, Powerpoint, Paint and others combined in one.

Sure, in my country not everyone is rich enough to get a simple iPad mini even, which is a real shame since everyone in class could jot things down like me and share it with others.

I'm only in high school, but I prefer simple paper and pencil. Maybe I'd like OneNote better if I seriously looked into it, but right now I don't really want to depend on a laptop or iPad for all my notes. I just like being able to hold the notes in my hand and say "BAM! Here they are!"

Nope, since your OneNote is stored in the cloud and will never get lost. Besides, you can share it with others and

it has a lot more features that a notepad. Try ripping out a website page and sticking it into your paper notepad lol, or attaching a pdf to your notepad. You'd end up with a huge briefcase full of papers.

Though for OneNote a Windows tablet would be best like the Venus 8 Pro or the SUrface Pro which is really optimized for it.

I would have killed for a laptop for note-taking in school.

TBH, considering my speed and legibility, I don't even feel like I would be honest in saying "I can write."

My ability to communicate through the written word exists solely because of keyboards. I had to write notes in school that were so short-hand (was the only way I could keep up with the teacher) that it made L33tspeak seem easy to understand. And even then my hand was cramping halfway through the class.
